nodes.whoTheyAre: Malala Yousafzai is an activist for female education and the youngest person ever to win a Nobel Peace Prize.
nodes.whyListen:
Malala Yousafzai is the cofounder of Malala Fund. She began her campaign for education at age 11 when she anonymously blogged for the BBC about life under the Taliban in Pakistan's Swat Valley. Inspired by her father's activism, she soon began advocating publicly for girls' education, attracting international media attention and awards.

At age 15, Yousafzai was shot by the Taliban for speaking out. She recovered in the United Kingdom and continued her fight for girls. In 2013, she founded Malala Fund. A year later, she received the Nobel Peace Prize in recognition of her advocacy for 12 years of free, safe, quality education for every child.

Yousafzai recently completed a degree in Philosophy, Politics and Economics at Oxford University.

nodes.whoTheyAre: Whitney Pennington Rodgers is an award-winning journalist and media professional.
nodes.whyListen:
Prior to joining TED as current affairs curator, Whitney Pennington Rodgers produced for NBC's primetime news magazine Dateline NBC. She earned a duPont-Columbia award and a News & Documentary Emmy or her contributions to the Dateline NBC hour "The Cosby Accusers Speak" -- an extensive group interview with 27 of the women who accused entertainer Bill Cosby of sexual misconduct.
Pennington Rodgers has worked at NBC's in-house production company Peacock Productions, The Today Show, Nightly News, Rock Center with Brian Williams and New Jersey-centric public affairs shows Caucus: New Jersey and One-on-One with Steve Adubato. Prior to beginning her career in media, she had a short stint as a fourth-grade teacher through the Teach for America program.
Pennington Rodgers received her Bachelor's in journalism and media studies from Rutgers University. She completed her Master's of Journalism at the University of California at Berkeley, where she produced a documentary about recruitment of nonblack students at historically black colleges and universities.

videoData.description: Education activist (and recent Oxford graduate) Malala Yousafzai reflects on the defining moments of her life, how she balances passion with personhood and where the world finds itself during the COVID-19 crisis. With humor and humility, she shares her dreams of seeing social progress in her lifetime, explains why girls education advocacy must not relent during the pandemic and champions youth activists worldwide leading the fight for a fairer future for all. (This virtual conversation, hosted by TED's current affairs curator Whitney Pennington Rodgers, was recorded July 8, 2020.)

footnotes.annotation:
> "And there are 130 million girls who do not have access to [education].”

This estimate comes from a 2016 UNESCO report that is based on data from 2014. For more, [see here](https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000245238).

> “So Malala Fund started like probably 5-6 years ago.”

The Malala Fund was started in 2013. For more, [see here](https://malala.org/about).

> “I was in refugee camps. I was in Nigeria, I was speaking for the girls who were abducted by Boko Haram. I went to Iraq as well. And I have been to Brazil as well…”

Yousafzai visited Nigeria in 2014 and 2017 ([here](https://www.cnn.com/2014/07/14/world/africa/nigeria-boko-haram-malala/index.html) and [here](https://www.unicef.org/nigeria/stories/education-key-malala-visits-schoolgirls-displaced-boko-haram-crisis-northeast-nigeria)). Yousafzai's visits to Iraq and Brazil took place in 2017 and 2018, respectively. For more on this, see [here](https://www.npr.org/2017/07/15/537381210/malala-yousafzai-turns-20-travels-to-iraq) and [here](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jul/12/malala-yousafzai-slams-trump-for-cruel-child-separations).

> “One was Najlaa. And she's a Yazidi refugee in a camp in Iraq…”

This section refers to Najlaa Hussin, a young Yazidi woman whom Yousafzai met in Iraq in 2017. For more on Hussin, see [here](https://blog.malala.org/not-even-early-marriage-or-isis-can-stop-these-two-yazidi-girls-from-completing-their-education-62bfd0aaf9d6) and [here](https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2018/02/14/585152138/yazidi-women-finally-go-to-school-defying-former-isis-rulers-and-their-own-paren).

> “In Lebanon, they are using these small electronic devices called Tabshoura, which has all the educational content that those children need for their age. And, you know, it does not require that much electricity, it can be connected to multiple computers. And they're very helpful in refugee camps. And they're using the Syrian refugee girls. And they're also trying to promote it on the sort of country level in Lebanon as well.”

This section is reference to Nayla Fayed's work on a digital education platform in Lebanon, which receives support from the Malala Fund's Education Championship Network. For more on this work, see [here](https://malala.org/newsroom/archive/tabshoura), [here](https://malala.org/newsroom/archive/leading-local-solutions-education-lebanon-nayla-fahed-global-refugee-forum) and [here](https://malala.org/newsroom/archive/nayla-interview).

> “... sort of a billion girls who will not be ready to participate in the task for requirements that are needed at that time. And it was one of the studies that Malala Fund conducted showed us...”

For more on this research by the Malala Fund, [see here](https://indd.adobe.com/view/dd1081b1-39b6-4637-9c61-ac0cbb275b45?startpage=9).

> “To be honest, when I started my activism as a 10 or 11 year old girl…”

Yousafzai was 11-years-old when she first published a diary blog for BBC Urdu in January 2009. For more, [see here](https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-19899540).
